citations.narrative:
A current record of guinea pigs on hand was not available for review. A total of 83 adult guinea pigs and 4 offspring were
counted during this inspection. There were no records of the number of guinea pigs held or died since June 8, 2024.
Failure to maintain records can make it difficult to assess the health of the caviary by identifying animal losses by
decreased number of guinea pigs born or raised. Licensee must maintain records containing the required information for
animals which disclose the number of guinea pigs held, owned, or disposed of including births and deaths. Correct by
August 31, 2024.

Structural strength. The side window in the guinea pig room had a large hole with broken glass present. A plastic garbage
bag was partially covering the window on left side of the large hole, but the wind was blowing the bag away from the hole.
The broken window could allow pests and other animals to enter the animal room. Housing facilities for animals must be
structurally sound, maintained in good repair, protect the guinea pigs from injury, and restrict the entrance of other
animals and pests. Correct by repairing or replacing the broken window.

There were accumulations of dried excreta (feces) and debris covering the floors of 8 of the 10 guinea pig enclosures.
The primary enclosures for the guinea pigs are not being cleaned and sanitized adequately or often enough to remove
excreta and debris. Ineffective cleaning and sanitation can expose the guinea pigs to disease hazards and health
problems. Correct by ensuing that all primary enclosures are kept clean to prevent accumulations of excreta and debris,
and that the enclosures are sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by August 22, 2024.

Housekeeping. The floor in the animal room contains accumulations of loose hay, spilled feed, and debris. There are
cobwebs, dirt, and debris covering the walls, ceiling, drainpipe, and equipment. Animal facilities must be kept clean to
ensure good quality of the air for the animals and to prevent unnecessary disease and health risks. Correct by ensuring
the premises are kept clean, including: removing hay, spilled feed, and debris from the floor and under racks; cleaning
cobwebs, dust, and debris from walls, ceiling, drainpipes and equipment; and maintaining a level of cleanliness to support
good husbandry and health.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a family member.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
A current record of guinea pigs on hand was not available for review. A total of 83 adult guinea pigs and 4 offspring were 
counted during this inspection. There were no records of the number of guinea pigs held or died since June 8, 2024. 
Failure to maintain records can make it difficult to assess the health of the caviary by identifying animal losses by 
decreased number of guinea pigs born or raised. Licensee must maintain records containing the required information for 
animals which disclose the number of guinea pigs held, owned, or disposed of including births and deaths. Correct by 
August 31, 2024. 
3.25(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
Structural strength. The side window in the guinea pig room had a large hole with broken glass present. A plastic garbage 
bag was partially covering the window on left side of the large hole, but the wind was blowing the bag away from the hole. 
The broken window could allow pests and other animals to enter the animal room. Housing facilities for animals must be 
structurally sound, maintained in good repair, protect the guinea pigs from injury, and restrict the entrance of other 
animals and pests. Correct by repairing or replacing the broken window. 
3.31(a)(1) 
   
Sanitation. 
There were accumulations of dried excreta (feces) and debris covering the floors of 8 of the 10 guinea pig enclosures. 
The primary enclosures for the guinea pigs are not being cleaned and sanitized adequately or often enough to remove 
excreta and debris. Ineffective cleaning and sanitation can expose the guinea pigs to disease hazards and health 
problems. Correct by ensuing that all primary enclosures are kept clean to prevent accumulations of excreta and debris, 
and that the enclosures are sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by August 22, 2024. 
3.31(b)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
Housekeeping. The floor in the animal room contains accumulations of loose hay, spilled feed, and debris. There are 
cobwebs, dirt, and debris covering the walls, ceiling, drainpipe, and equipment. Animal facilities must be kept clean to 
ensure good quality of the air for the animals and to prevent unnecessary disease and health risks. Correct by ensuring

the premises are kept clean, including: removing hay, spilled feed, and debris from the floor and under racks; cleaning 
cobwebs, dust, and debris from walls, ceiling, drainpipes and equipment; and maintaining a level of cleanliness to support 
good husbandry and health. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a family member.
